The University of the Arts (UNA) in London announced today that it will open a new, state-of-the-art research and teaching space designed by British architect Sir Richard Foster and the German company Guggenheim Aurten in the campus of the museum.Established in the garden of the British Royal Institute of British Architects (BRIC), the building will be a graduate learning facility that will address the needs of a number of academic disciplines, including architecture and design, design and landscape, and design and urban design.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York announced today that it is preparing to welcome visitors back to the museum after a mysterious and devastating fire tore through the institution in March 2019, killing eighteen people and injuring more than one hundred. The fire, which was extinguished by firefighters only seventy-eight hours later, was extinguished only after the museum’s glass-enclosed exterior façade, which houses the museum’s four galleries, was razed to the ground.The firemen who extinguished the blaze, which took place in an eighteenth-century brick building on the museum’s second floor, found that the building, which was constructed in 1972, did not suffer structural damage. The building had been boarded up since 2007, when it housed the museum’s permanent collection. The American Institute of Architects, which designed the building, had originally awarded the museum a B+ for its design in 2017, but the institution claims the B+ was changed to an A+ after a public inquiry.
